result.text:
Sentiments of Venezuelans

Iâ€™m going to say this once, and I donâ€™t care if it makes people uncomfortable.

If you have never lived in Venezuela
If you did not grow up there
If you did not watch your country collapse in real time
If you did not stand in food lines
If you did not watch your parents lose everything they built
If you did not have to leave your home with nothing

Then shut the fuck up.

You do not have an opinion.
Your opinion does not matter.
And you donâ€™t get to lecture anyone about whatâ€™s happening there.

Iâ€™m Venezuelan.
I lived there most of my life until my early twenties.
I watched my country go from a functioning democracy to full blown socialism right in front of my eyes.

This is not politics to me.
This is trauma.

Before socialism, Venezuela was not perfect, but it worked.
There was trade.
There was money coming in.
There was investment from the US.
There were jobs.
There was food.
There was medicine.

My family had five businesses.
We had our home
We had investments.
We had a future.

Then the government started nationalizing everything.
Private companies were taken.
Foreign investors were pushed out.
Imports were blocked.
Price controls destroyed production.
Corruption exploded.

And everything died.

Not slowly.
Violently.

People didnâ€™t suddenly become poor because of â€œcapitalismâ€ or â€œthe USâ€ or whatever bullshit slogan people like to repeat online.

They became poor because socialism destroyed incentives, destroyed production, destroyed trust, and destroyed hope.

People today in Venezuela are not debating ideology.
They are trying to survive.

They are trying to find food.
Trying to find medication.
Trying to keep their families alive.

So when I see people in the West posting from comfortable homes, full fridges, stable currencies, and safe streets talking about â€œimperialismâ€ or â€œUS badâ€ or â€œTrump this or thatâ€

No.
Itâ€™s not complicated.
Youâ€™re just ignorant.

China is not rebuilding Venezuela.
Russia is not rebuilding Venezuela.
Cartels are not rebuilding Venezuela.

They are stealing.
They are extracting.
They are draining whatâ€™s left.

If the US comes in and reinvests
If refineries get rebuilt
If infrastructure gets restored
If imports open back up
If food, water, and medicine become accessible again
If people can work and earn with dignity

Then yes.
Let them take all the oil they want.

Because at least something gets built instead of destroyed.

This is something to celebrate.
Not because itâ€™s perfect.
But because for the first time in a long time, there is hope.

Hope that families can eat.
Hope that people donâ€™t have to flee their country.
Hope that Venezuela can function again.

If youâ€™ve never lived through a country collapsing
If youâ€™ve never watched socialism destroy everything around you
If youâ€™ve never had to leave your home because staying meant starvation

Then again
Shut the fuck up.

This isnâ€™t theory.
This isnâ€™t politics.
This is lived experience.

By Stephen Subero

legacy.description: Chat freely. Fully encrypted messaging powered by X.

result.text:
X cannot read your messages. We back up your private keys to our hardware security modules (HSMs) to make recovering your message history on new devices frictionless. These HSMs were initialized in our published key ceremony: https://t.co/773cq3qnNP 

Your keys can only be recovered from the HSMs by entering your PIN correctly. The limit on the number of guesses for the PIN is set to 20 by default (this can be verified through the key fetch response and cannot be disabled after registration), after which the keys self-destruct, meaning no one at X can reliably brute force your PIN to recover your keys.

We're always improving X Chat and aim to boost security even further without hurting the user experience on X. The goal of X Chat is to be the communication system for Earth. Privacy and usability are core. We offer end-to-end encrypted messages, with no ad hooks and no dependency on AWS like other messaging services. Enhanced privacy features such as opt-in self custody and forward secrecy are on our roadmap.

result.text:
Creative Minds Daycare was shut down on October 1, 2025, due to multiple licensing violations identified by the Minnesota Department of Human Services (DHS). These included issues like inadequate supervision, safety hazards, and record-keeping failures.

The center reopened the very next day, October 2, 2025, under the new name Super Kids Daycare at the same address, using what appears to be the same or a transferred license.

In fiscal year 2025 (which ran from July 1, 2024, to June 30, 2025), Super Kids Daycare received approximately $2.45 million in payments through Minnesota's Child Care Assistance Program. 

Who is the owner of this "daycare"?
State Sen. Omar Fateh's brother-in-law, Mohamud Muse.

Muse, who volunteered for the campaign of DFL State Sen. Omar Fateh (his brother-in-law), admitted to collecting ballots from voters but falsely denied under oath that he had paid or coerced anyone. He was convicted in May 2022 of one count of perjury for lying to a federal grand jury about his role in handling and delivering absentee ballots during the August 2020 primary election in Minneapolis.

result.text:
ð—–ð—µð—¶ð—²ð—³ ð—ð˜‚ð˜€ð˜ð—¶ð—°ð—² ð—¥ð—¼ð—¯ð—²ð—¿ð˜ð˜€'ð˜€ ð—™ð—¿ð—®ð˜‚ð—±ð˜‚ð—¹ð—²ð—»ð˜ ð—¨ð˜€ð—² ð—¼ð—³ ð—§ð—µð—¼ð—ºð—®ð˜€ ð—£ð—®ð—¶ð—»ð—²

Chief Justice Roberts's invocation of Thomas Paine is not reverence. It is appropriation.

In his 2025 Year-End Report on the Federal Judiciary marking the 250th anniversary of Common Sense, Roberts praises the pamphlet that "electrified the country" and reassures the public that the Constitution remains "firm and unshaken." The implication: Paine's radical spirit animates the modern Court.

It does not.

Paine was not a celebrant of institutions for their own sake. Common Sense was an attack, on concentrated power, executive prerogative, and the habit of obeying simply because authority cloaks itself in law. Paine distrusted kings, courts, and elites precisely because they claimed legitimacy while insulating themselves from accountability.

His constitutional creed was unmistakable:

"IN AMERICA, THE LAW IS KING."

Not the president. Not the Court. Not stability, tradition, or convenience. The law, applied equally to rulers and ruled.

Now consider what Roberts's Court has done.

In Trump v. United States, the Court invented a doctrine of presidential immunity for "official acts." It appears nowhere in the Constitution. It was recognized by no founding-era court, defended by no framer, grounded in no text, structure, or original public meaning. It was conjured to shield a particular president from accountability, and blessed by justices who otherwise insist that constitutional meaning was fixed in 1788.

This is not originalism. It is opportunism in originalist dress.

Paine would have recognized the maneuver instantly. He warned that tyranny rarely arrives by proclamation. It advances gradually, blessed by institutions that mistake legality for justice and authority for legitimacy.

"When I contemplate the natural dignity of man," Paine wrote, "I become irritated at the attempt to govern mankind by force and fraud."

Force and fraud. The force of executive power untethered from Congress. The fraud of invoking the founders while betraying their design.

The founders feared one danger above all others: the concentration of power in a single executive. They had fought a war against it. They constructed a constitutional architecture to prevent it, enumerated powers, legislative control over war, separation of powers enforced through rivalry, not trust.

Roberts praises this architecture in the abstract. His Court erodes it in practice.

Presidential immunity for "official acts." Tolerance of unilateral war-making. Deference to boundless emergency powers. Authority steadily migrating from the branch the framers empowered to the branch they feared.

The asymmetry is impossible to ignore.

When Trump asserts power, the Court discovers doctrine to accommodate him. Immunity appears. Emergencies expand. Challenges are delayed until they dissolve. When Biden acted, constraints multiplied. Skepticism sharpened. Doctrines materialized to restrain.

The Constitution does not change with the occupant of the Oval Office. But the Court's posture appears to. That is not neutral adjudication. It is politics in a robe.

Paine named this habit: accepting as right whatever authority has sanctioned. Common Sense was written to break that spell, to remind citizens that institutions can betray their purposes while insisting on their own rectitude.

Roberts wants Paine's moral authority without Paine's courage. He quotes "these are the times that try men's souls" while presiding over a Court that has made the trials easier for those with power and harder for those without.

His report invokes Lincoln, Susan B. Anthony, and Martin Luther King Jr., a lineage of moral struggle, yet offers solace when the moment demands resistance. It speaks of endurance when the issue is accountability.

Paine did not write to comfort institutions. He wrote to unsettle them when they failed. He revered no office, no robe, no ruler, only the principle that no one stands above the law.

"IN AMERICA, THE LAW IS KING."

A Court that manufactures presidential immunity, defers to unilateral war, and applies different standards depending on who holds power does not honor that principle. It mocks it.

To invoke Paine while enabling what Jefferson and Madison called "elective despotism" is not homage. It is betrayal, of Paine, of constitutional design, and of the public the Court claims to serve.

Paine wrote to dethrone kings. Roberts cites him while crowning one.

She grew up in luxury in Hyde Park, attended elite private schools, and is the child of William and Catherine DeFoor ,both prominent pediatric doctors whoâ€™ve donated thousands to Democratic causes, including Kamala Harris and Joe Biden.

No motive has been released, but the suspect has a prior criminal record, including a guilty plea for vandalizing an interior design firm in 2024.

Jehoshaphat Research is pleased to share some good news about your right to speak freely. 

We have obtained a partial summary judgment court ruling that our February 2023 report relating to Techtronicâ€™s accounting, financial condition, and management were not defamation as a matter of law.

This is an important and courageous ruling that vindicates the First Amendment rights of individuals to comment on the activities of major corporations.

Separately, the Courtâ€™s ruling permits Techtronic to continue to pursue its claims regarding a follow-up report we wrote in June 2023, in which we discussed Techtronicâ€™s relationship with Home Depot. We will continue to defend ourselves against those claims. Our arguments will speak for themselves, in open court. 

We also intend to post updates of the case on our website in our new â€œLawsuitsâ€ section.

core.name: The Center for Studies of the South Caucasus

legacy.description: CSSC is a independent research organization based in Baku, Azerbaijan, focusing on the political & economic processes in the South Caucasus and its neighborhood

result.text:
External Influences on the Peace Process and How to Address Them

The South Caucasus is, by its nature, a region highly susceptible to conflict. Geography, history, economic potential (including transport routes and energy resources), and proximity to major powers all create conditions for constant competition over the region among foreign actors. At times, this competition escalates into open confrontation.

To understand the regional dynamics, we must first identify who is competing with whom and the nature of that competition - whether geopolitical, economic, or military-political - based on the intensity of each relationship.

Three Neighbors: Turkey, Russia, Iran

These three countries compete with each other while maintaining situational partnerships. All dimensions of competition - geopolitical, military-political, and economic - are present in their interactions. These relationships can be characterized as competitive partnerships. The neighbors maintain communication channels and extensive bilateral relations, with the South Caucasus serving as one of several regions where their interests converge.

EU vs. Russia - This relationship is defined by geopolitical and economic competition. Given the entrenched nature of the conflict, competition is expected only to intensify in the medium term.

US vs. Russia - Geopolitical and economic competition dominates this relationship. Under President Trump, relations may shift from direct confrontation toward competitive partnership.

US vs. Iran, Israel vs. Iran - These relationships are characterized by geopolitical and military components. Relations between the US, Israel, and Iran remain on the brink of direct military conflict. However, the South Caucasus currently lies outside the primary conflict zone.

India vs. Pakistan - Geopolitical and, to some extent, economic competition defines this relationship. While the South Caucasus remains geographically distant for both countries, they participate in the militarization of Azerbaijan and Armenia and leverage their positions in international organizations to advance their regional competition.

China vs. US - Geopolitical and economic competition characterizes this relationship. The South Caucasus represents a third-tier priority for these global powers. However, as US and Chinese involvement in the region increases, their competition becomes more apparent.

France vs. Turkey, Greece vs. Turkey - Geopolitical competition drives these relationships. Paris and Athens consistently attempt to form coalitions against Ankara in the Eastern Mediterranean, with a role envisioned for Armenia within these efforts.

Israel vs. Turkey - Geopolitical competition defines this relationship. The ongoing conflict in the Middle East regularly impacts the South Caucasus, particularly Azerbaijan.

The peace agenda between Azerbaijan and Armenia will establish new parameters for the region, and competition among foreign actors may either intensify or become irrelevant. Foreign actors are currently evaluating the peace agenda. Some are actively participating in the process, others are preparing for the implementation of its outcomes, while still others are attempting to obstruct peace, unable to envision alternative means of pursuing their interests beyond conflict management.

It is neither possible to prohibit foreign actors from projecting power, nor prudent to ignore their intentions. However, it is possible to manage this projection of power by establishing frameworks for its implementation and adopting a pragmatic approach. Azerbaijan and Georgia possess extensive experience in reconciling the power projection of stronger foreign actors with their national interests. Today, the most pressing priority is the establishment of such frameworks between Azerbaijan and Armenia, and subsequently at the trilateral level. This essentially involves establishing principles of interaction among regional countries and determining rules of engagement that foreign actors will be compelled to observe.

The TRIPP project exemplifies this approach. Azerbaijan and Armenia have reached a bilateral agreement on US participation in the communications corridor initiative. The success of TRIPP can and should replicate the success of the Deal of the Century.

Foreign actors may possess both the desire and resources to use regional countries as instruments to advance their competition with other powers, but they should not have the opportunity to do so. Regardless of their size and power, foreign actors must understand and respect the rules and frameworks that regional countries establish for these processes.

result.text:
People often say that the developing world is poor because the Western world colonized them and stole their resources. 

The truth, however, is that over the past century, the developing world has, for the most part, shown that they are completely incapable of harnessing their own resources. They are not poor because we stole from them. They are poor because they do not know how to run and administer their own countries, resources be damned.

Take Venezuela. The world's largest oil reserves mean nothing if you have a corrupt communist as your leader. People will actually be starving and trying to eat zoo animals while you sit on trillions of dollars in resources!

Africa is another example. Europeans left behind farmland, trains, roads, and mines in Africa. What happened to it all?

It's not that all of a sudden, the Africans started running things like anti-colonialist activists had envisioned at the time. No, no.

All the infrastructure fell into disrepair and/or was stripped down and looted. They were literally handed fully functioning, completed supply chains for resource extraction, and basically unlimited wealth, but they couldn't manage the simple upkeep.

Now, the defense for Africa might be that "The Europeans didn't teach the Africans how to manage any of this! It's not the Africans' fault they couldn't run it independently! They were never trained!"

But my brother in Christ, the Europeans DID try to train locals for management! Obviously it would have been easier to have at least some locals in administration, rather than having to import an ENTIRE workforce, but efforts to find African talent were largely unsuccessful.

Don't believe me? Just look at the different outcomes in Hong Kong and Singapore when compared to Africa. In East Asia, Europeans often did work with locals in administrative and management capacities. When colonialism ended, Hong Kong and Singapore were able to manage themselves. Not the case with Africa.

Now, none of this is to say that colonialism is good. People have the right to self-rule and seld-determination. However, the idea that colonialism and resources extraction are responsible for the developing world's ongoing poverty? That is quite simply a crock of shit.

result.text:
Great quote from Cicero:

â€A nation can survive its fools, and even the ambitious. But it cannot survive treason from within. 

An enemy at the gates is less formidable, for he is known and he carries his banners openly. But the traitor moves among those within the gate freely, his sly whispers rustling through all the galleys, heard in the very hall of government itself. 

For the traitor appears not traitor - he speaks in the accents familiar to his victims, and wears their face and their garments, and he appeals to the baseness that lies deep in the hearts of all men. 

He rots the soul of a nation - he works secretly and unknown in the night to undermine the pillars of a city - he infects the body politic so that it can no longer resist. 

A murderer is less to be feared.â€
